title: Flask World Cup Predictions Site
subtitle: Flask site that's used to run a predictions league
description: A flask project I'm working on for friends and family, the site will be used for a predictions league during the 2026 world cup. For the project I've had to learn new skills and improve current ones, for example I've had to improve my knowledge of Python and web development as well learn how to use the Flask framework.

title: Masquer Plague
subtitle: 2026 Global Game Jam Project
description:
Very silly game in godot that I worked on during the 2026 global game jam, in Masquer Plague you take on the role of a plague doctor who must 'cure' infected visitors, use your special mask to work out who's infected but be careful not to scare too many guests!
I was one of two programmers, alongside three artists in a team of five.
I mainly worked on the NPC/Enemy systems and on how the different furniture was both created and how it affected NPC travel.
This was my first major project in Godot, and so a lot of the time I spent on this project was on learning the basics of the engine, we used C# for the programming which in hindsight was a mistake as most documentation is focused on GD Script and often complicated the learning process for me.
For future projects in the engine I'll be using GD Script instead.

title: SFML Framework
subtitle: Basic framework for SFML Projects
description: SFML Framework that I worked on in prepartion for fourth year modules, specifically I worked on the game loop components, as well as the basic entities and collision detection (Which I'd quite like to update!)

title: OpenGL Bookstore Scene
description:
OpenGL scene created for second year university coursework.
The scene makes use of many OpenGL features, such as procedurally generated books and bookshelves, model loading, use of the stencil buffer, transparency, and lighting.

title: Bullet Types and Status Effects Mechanic
subtitle: Unreal Engine 5 C++ project where different bullets apply different effects to objects in the scene
description:
Game mechanic made in Unreal Engine 5 as part of third-year university coursework.
The project was fully made using C++ with minimal blueprint useage for UI.
The mechanic uses a status effects component to apply different effects to placeholder enemies based on the bullet type fired:
  • Set enemies on fire dealing damage over time, the fire spreads to other burnable enemies
  • Turn enemies into the centre of a gravity field, pulling other objects and enemies toward them
  • Turn an enemy into a stacking bomb that explodes after a time and is stronger the more times it is applied
When taking damage the placeholder enemies will flash and display the damage recently taken.

title: Two in the Chamber
subtitle: PS5 Arena fighter where two players can collect different weapons, made using the Skateboard Engine
description:
Two in the Chamber is a two-player platform fighter for the PS5 made using an in-house engine, 'Skateboard', as part of university coursework.
Two players control their respective characters that can use different weapons with different characteristics to fight one another, as well as collect upgrades to improve their strength.
I worked on the game in a group as one of three programmers and tackled lots of different challenges.
While I primarily worked on the weapon systems, like how the different weapons interacted with the player, I also worked on the player upgrade system, and a dynamic music system so that the music would remain seamless between the splash screen, menus, and gameplay.

title: Bullet Hell Infinite
subtitle: Infinite runner bullet hell made using SFML
description:
Made as part of first year university coursework using SFML and C++, Bullet Hell Infinite is an infinite runner game where the player must dodge dozens of projectiles and enemies to survive.
While playing different power-ups can be collected to empower to player and change how their ship behaves:
  • Double Shot
  • Triple Shot
  • Super Speed
  • Invincibility
  • Healing
At the end of a game the player's score is saved to a file and the top scores can be viewed from the menu.

title: Galactic Postal Servitude

description:
Point and click puzzle game where you approve and deny parcels being sent by aliens.
First worked on as a university project, it was later massively improved during DARE Academy.
DARE Academy is the premier game development competion hosted by Abertay University, 6 teams make the final after an application and interview round.
Following four weeks of hot housing and an open play event, an ultimate winner is decided upon by a panel of industry judges.
For this project I worked as one of two programmers, alongside artists, desginers, an audio designer, and a producer.
The game was made in Unreal Engine 5 and as a programmer I worked on many differnt parts of the design, from UI to scoring mechanics, improving my skills with each new feature.

  • Stamping
  • Journal system

  • Scoring system

  • Parcel generation rework

title: DirectX 11 River Scene
description: Direct X11 scene created as university coursework. The scene features a Gerstner wave simulation as well as a controllable riverbed alongside multiple light types and shadows.
features:
Features

  • Gerstner wave simulation
  • Customisable river terrain
  • Dynamic and static tessellation
  • Bloom with compute shader
  • Directional, spot, and point lights
  • Depth map shadows
  • Model loading
  • Blinn-Phong specular highlights
